section.title: Basic Needs Statement
section.p: PCC wants you to be successful and have resources that may help. If you face challenges affording food or housing, or if you need access to technology, this will naturally affect your classwork. Check out these resources: Student COVID-19 Resources and Emergency Funds. You can also contact a campus Student Conduct and Retention Coordinator at conductandcare@pcc.edu.

section.title: Contact Information
section.p: To reach me or PCC:

cell.line: Office: CA SSB 317 when PCC opens
(Use Zoom and email to contact me.)
(Not a good way to reach me this term.)

section.p: Because of federal privacy laws, all email communications related to this class need to be sent to and from your @pcc.edu email address.
Office hours are by appointment. Just send me an email suggesting some times, and we'll set up a meeting on Zoom. I'm not available MW 9:0011:50 (obviously), MW 2:004:20, and TuTh 11:301:50.
Come visit me (virtually) for help with the material, help with homework, or questions about your grade.
While I do have an office phone number and voice mail, I am more likely to reply to you more quickly if you use email to contact me.

section.title: Course Description
section.p: Taken from the official PCC course description:

Includes limits, continuity, derivatives and some applications of derivatives. Graphing technology is required, such as Desmos and/or GeoGebra which are available at no cost. Prerequisites: (MTH 112 or CMET 131) and (WR 115 and RD 115) or IRW 115 or equivalent placement. Audit available.
The complete Course Content and Outcome Guide can be found at www.pcc.edu/ccog/.

section.title: Expectations
section.p: This term we are responding to the coronavirus pandemic. The physcial buildings at PCC are closed, and we cannot conduct the usual face-to-face instruction that we are all used to (both as students and as instructors).

We all have extra responsibilities this term. As the instructor, I need to find new ways to deliver the instruction to you at home. I need to be creative and flexible with how we use technology. And you, the student, need to have the self-discipline to complete everything that I ask of you. And also to be brave and bring all of your concerns and questions to me as soon as you can.

We can boil down your responsibilities to the following list.
Sign in to the live sessions we will have in Zoom every Monday and Wednesday at 9:00. I will give a brief overview of the important points of the day, and I will take your questions, including questions you have about examples and exercises. Then we will usually move to the lab portion of the class.
If you have to miss all or part of a class session, watch the recording of the overview portion.
Collaborate with your lab partners on the lab assignments during our live sessions. When needed, continue to collaborate with your lab partners outside of class. Your lab group must complete write-ups of each lab by its due date.
If you have to miss a lab session, complete the lab on your own by its due date.
Read sections of the textbook ahead of class. We will not be using class time to demonstrate examples, which is common in an in-person classroom setting. It would not be the best use of our time.
Watch the videos that are embedded in the version of the textbook that I am directing you to. My colleague at University of Lethbridge produced these videos and they were made for our book specifically.
Complete the homework exercises that are assigned in . There will be a problem set associated to each section of the textbook that we cover.
Complete the weekly quiz that is assigned in . Each quiz is timed, and uses the questions from homework where the class had the least amount of success. This is intended to motivate you to do all of the homework and ask questions when you do not understand something yet.
Use all the tools available to you to communicate with me about your concerns and your questions.
Direct Email
D2L Discussion Posts (can be posted anonymously)
Raising issues during the Zoom sessions
Schedule one-on-one Zoom meeting with me

section.title: Technology Requirements
section.p: Since we are in a remote teaching mode, it is essential that you have access to a computer, laptop, tablet, or at the very least a smart phone. And you need internet access. Ideally, your device and internet connection will work with the Zoom sessions, but otherwise you can call in to the Zoom meetings. You do not need to purchase or install Zoom.

We will be using Google Docs for the labs and lab write-ups. As a PCC student, you have access to Google Docs. Typically I will simply send you a link to a Google Doc as needed. You may access all of your Google Docs by using PCC Gmail, and using the 33 icon in the upper right.
Homework and quizzes use . You log in to your account using a web browser.

section.title: Textbook
section.p: We are using a free textbook written by Greg Hartman at the Virginia Military Institute. The book is called APEX Calculus.

Access this book:
as a free HTML book at www.cs.uleth.ca/~fitzpat/apex-calculus.
in various PDF forms at www.apexcalculus.com/.
for purchase from the PCC book store for $16.00. (PCC will ship it to you for free this term during the virus response.)

introduction.p: General PCC Grading Guidelines are found at catalog.pcc.edu/handbook/g301-gradingguidelines.

paragraphs.title: Labs
paragraphs.p: Most class days, you will work in small groups on a collection of exercises from the PCC Calculus Lab Manual. Work on these diligently during class time with your partners, and then turn in a completed lab write-up. You and your partners might finish during class, but you may need to arrange to meet with each other after class. You need to complete each lab write-up before the next class meets.
If you miss class, you may complete the lab on your own and turn it in before the next class.
One grade will be assigned for each lab write-up. All group memebers share the grade. Each lab write-up is worth 2% of your final grade, for a total of 28%.

paragraphs.title: Online Homework
paragraphs.p: You have online homework for each section using . See for details. The due date for each assignment is posted in . It will always be Tuesday evening at 10:00pm. Usually, more than one section will be due at the same time. You should start working on a homework assignment soon after the class that is associated with that section of APEX.
Collectively, all the online homework is worth 6% of your final grade.

paragraphs.title: Quizzes
paragraphs.p: You have weekly quizzes using . Each homework assignment is due on a Tuesday evening. I will build a quiz that uses those homework questions for which there was the least overall success, but still appropriate for a 1-hour time limit. This is intended to motivate you to do all of the homework and ask questions when you do not understand something yet. You take these quizzes when you are able to, but they must be completed by Friday evening at 10:00pm. Each quiz is worth 2% and there are 8 quizzes, for a total of 16%.

paragraphs.title: Exams
paragraphs.p: The final exam will be Monday June 8. Hopefully it will be on campus, in our classroom TH 200, 9:0011:50. At this time we can't be sure. The final exam will be worth 25% of your grade.

There will also be a midterm exam. Because of the virus response, its format and location are not yet known. Tentatively, it will be an in-person exam in our classroom TH 200, 9:0011:50, on Wednesday May 6. The midterm will be worth 25% of your grade.

section.title: Course Downloads
section.p: If there are files to download for this course, you will be able to access them here.

section.title: WeBWorK Assignments
section.p: I have made an account for you on a program called at webwork.pcc.edu/webwork2/mth251-jordan-202002. Each week there are problem sets and you are required to answer them online using . The topics that we cover in a week have exercises that are typically due Tuesday of the following week at 10:00, but can be worked on much earlier. You may submit answers any time before the due date. You may work from home or use PCC computer labs to turn in your answers.
Here is an example of what a problem is like.

statement.p: Use the properties of exponents to simplify .

solution.p: We add the exponents as follows: \amp=x^{+}\amp=x^{}

statement.p: Use the properties of exponents to simplify {x^{4}x^{3}}\text{.}

solution.p: We add the exponents as follows:

paragraphs.title: Why are we using WeBWorK?
paragraphs.p: Traditionally, homework comes from textbook problems that students would do on paper, and then turn in in to the instructor. One drawback of this is that students get no feedback at all until about a week later, and at that point the student is no longer actively thinking about material from two weeks earlier. Another drawback is that it is impossible for a student to do the appropriate amount of homework and for the instructor to give quality feedback for every single exercise. Often an instructor is only able to give feedback for a small subset of the exercises. Using brings the following advantages over traditional homework.

li.title: Cost
li.p: is free, unlike many online homework programs.

li.title: Timely Feedback
li.p: Rather than waiting a week for written feedback from your instructor, you get instant feedback from .

li.title: Quality Feedback
li.p: will do more than just tell you if you are right or wrong. For example, it will usually tell you if you haven't completely simplified an answer or forgot to include units when they are required. Sometimes it will do even more. Try entering x^12 as the answer to .

li.title: Ease of Communication
li.p: encourages you to write your instructor for help, who can provide even higher quality feedback based on your message and your previous attempts.

li.title: Multiple or Unlimited Attempts
li.p: On paper, when you submit an answer, that's the end of it. With you might get a problem wrong on your first attempt, but you are encouraged to figure out your mistakes and try again.

li.title: Efficient Use of Class Time
li.p: Your instructor can monitor the whole class and see in real-time which problems and concepts are causing the class difficulty.

li.title: Extra Practice
li.p: Your instructor can set things up so that you can retry each problem with new random numbers involved. If you are unsure if you have mastered a skill, this gives you a way to keep practicing.

paragraphs.title: Logging in to WeBWorK
paragraphs.p: Go directly to webwork.pcc.edu/webwork2/mth251-jordan-202002. If you are working at your own computer, you might want to bookmark this link. Your username is your PCC email prefix, using all lowercase letters. For example, mine is alex.jordan because my email address is alex.jordan@pcc.edu. Your initial password is your PCC G-number, using a capital G.

paragraphs.title: The First Time You Log On
paragraphs.p: You should go to the User Settings menu in the upper left and change your password. There is an Orientation assignment for you to take. Click on the Orientation, and begin by reading the paragraph to the right that says Read This First. Take the time to complete the Orientation, and you will understand a lot about how behaves. The Orientation will remain available to you for the entire term, so you can always come back and look at it again.

paragraphs.title: Homework Sets Menu
paragraphs.p:
This shows you the assignments that have been assigned to you and when they are due. You may:
click on an assignment and begin working on problems online
check the box next to an assignment and click Download Hardcopy to get the assignment as a .pdf file which you may then print to work on away from a computer.

When you click on an assignment, you will see a screen with the problem numbers listed. Off to the right is a message for you that might have specific instructions or information about the assignment. You should always look for and read this message.

paragraphs.title: Emailing for Help
paragraphs.p: When you are stumped, you can click the Email Instructor button at the bottom of any problem. Write a message explaining what you have tried and if possible, include the work from your calculations. will send your instructor an email with helpful information (like all of the incorrect attempts you have tried) and they get back to you soon with a response. When they respond, it will be with an email, so you must remember to check your email.

paragraphs.title: Math Achievements
paragraphs.p: As you complete more problems through the term, you will win badges for various achievements. For example, the On One Hand badge is for completing a homework set with fewer than five incorrect submissions. Both earning badges and just plain answering questions correctly will earn you achievement points. As you gain more achievement points, you will level up. Each time you level up, you earn an item that can be used to affect your grade.

li.title: Level 1: Lesser Rod of Revelation
li.p: Give yourself 50% credit on one problem.

li.title: Level 2: Potion of Forgetfulness
li.p: Drop the number incorrect attempts down to 0.

li.title: Level 3: Tunic of Extension
li.p: Extend the due date of a currently open homework for 24 hours.

li.title: Level 4: Cupcake of Enlargement
li.p: Double the weight of one problem.

li.title: Level 5: Box of Transmogrification
li.p: Change a single problem to be a (newly randomized) copy of a different problem on the same homework set.

li.title: Level 6: Greater Rod of Revelation
li.p: Give yourself 100% credit on one problem.

li.title: Level 7: Robe of Longevity
li.p: Extend the due date of a currently open homework for 48 hours.

li.title: Level 8: Scroll of Resurrection
li.p: Reopen a homework set (even a closed one) for an additional 24 hours. All problems will be re-randomized.

li.title: Level 9: Greater Tome of Enlightenment
li.p: Earn 100% on every problem in a single homework set.

li.title: Level 10: Cake of Enlargement
li.p: Double the weight of an entire set.

section.title: Exams
section.p: Because of the coronavirus response, we do not yet know all details of how exams will be administered or even on which days. It is possible there will be an in-person midterm on Wednesday May 6, and an in-person final exam on Monday June 8. If they are in-person, they will be in TH 200, 9:0011:50.
The midterm exam and the final exam will each be worth 25% of your final grade.

section.title: Student Resources
section.p: PCC wants you to be successful and have resources that may help. If you face challenges affording food or housing, or if you need access to technology, this will naturally affect your classwork. Check out these resources: Student COVID-19 Resources and Emergency Funds. You can also contact a campus Student Conduct and Retention Coordinator at conductandcare@pcc.edu.

paragraphs.title: ADA Accommodation
paragraphs.p: Students who experience disability-related barriers should contact Disability Services: www.pcc.edu/disability. If students elect to use approved academic adjustments, they must provide, in advance, formal notification from Disability Services to the instructor.

paragraphs.title: Email Notice
paragraphs.p: Due to Federal laws and concerns about privacy, all email communication between instructor and student shall be done via PCC assigned email address. Access email via MyPCCsee instructor during office hours if unfamiliar with using MyPCC.

paragraphs.title: Equity & Inclusion Nondiscrimination Nonharassment (Title IX)
paragraphs.p: Portland Community College is committed to creating and fostering a learning and working environment based on open communication and mutual respect. This is an integral part of the College's academic mission to enrich our students' educational experiences and prepare them to live in and contribute to a global society. If you believe you have encountered sexual harassment, sexual misconduct, sexual assault, or discrimination based on race, color, religion, age, national origin, veteran status, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, or disability please contact the Office of Equity and Inclusion at (971) 722-5840 or equity.inclusion@pcc.edu.

paragraphs.title: Flexibility Statement
paragraphs.p: The instructor reserves the right to modify course content and/or substitute assignments and learning activities in response to institutional, weather, or class situations. Flash Alert Messenger is a free service that delivers closure information: www.pcc.edu/about/announcements/closure-information.html

paragraphs.title: Sanctuary College
paragraphs.p: PCC is a sanctuary college. See: www.pcc.edu/resources/undocumented-students

paragraphs.title: Grading and Registration Policies and Deadlines
Student Rights and Responsibilities Handbook
paragraphs.p: Students are required to comply with the Student Rights and Responsibilities Handbook. Included are policies on Students Rights, Student Conduct, Grade Appeal, Academic Integrity, Consensual Relationship Statement, and Children on PCC properties.
